subject: RE: [junit] coverage testing
msgSnippet: As a mater of fact we do cover this case in Agitator because the solver knows this error case can occur but ... I don t want to sound like an advertisment and
messageBody:
As a mater of fact we do cover this case in Agitator because the solver knows this error case can occur but ...

I don't want to sound like an advertisment and this was intended to be more of a generic comment on how classic coverage rules does not "cut it" in an exception throwing language. So even if you have 100% code coverage there can still be nasty bugs lurking ....

________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Eugene Kuleshov
Sent: Monday, November 21, 2005 12:32 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] coverage testing


Kent,

Aren't you guys doing this already in Agitator?

regards,
Eugene


Kent Mitchell wrote:

>One other issue is that coverage (even path coverage) follows a classic interpretation of "paths" being based on the structure of the code. But for an exception throwing language there is other possible "paths" that are triggered by behavior of the called code. Consider:
>
> public static void int parse (String s) {
>
> return Integer.parseInt(s);
>
> }
>
>Classically this has exactly one code path and gets 100% coverage if you pass in "1234" but behaviorally it has two paths because parseInt can throw an exception. So ... you really need "data coverage" which is a nebulous concept to measure at best.
>
>
>
>Kent
>
>
>
>________________________________
>
>
>
>From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Cédric Beust ?
>
>Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 5:58 AM
>
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>
>Subject: Re: [junit] coverage testing
>
>
>
>
>
>On 11/16/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
>>On 16/11/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>>Nobody disputes that 100% code coverage is a good thing, it's just that
>>>
>>>
>
>
>
>>it
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>>becomes impossibly hard to achieve as your code base becomes more
>>>
>>>
>
>
>
>>complex.
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>>You just need to make sure you don't hit the point of diminishing return
>>>
>>>
>
>
>
>>>when trying to hit a balance between "more code coverage", "more tests",
>>>
>>>
>
>
>
>>>"bug fixes" and "more features".
>>>
>>>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>>The other part, of course, is that 100% code coverage still doesn't
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>mean you've tested everything... there will still be logic paths
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>through the code that are not exercised, and in any large enough
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>program (say, above 10000 lines), these paths rapidly approach
>>
>>
>
>
>
>>infiinty.
>>
>>
>
>
>
>
>
>Great point, and one that is often neglected by code coverage enthusiasts.
>
>
>
>--
>
>Cédric
>
>
>
>
